They would repeat three key messages in clear language: your data belongs to you and you can say no, fees and conditions are open and fair, and SokoLink must always make women’s trading lives easier, not harder. To measure trust beyond likes, we will compare before and after data on voluntary participation, complaint patterns, and whether women now feel comfortable challenging errors in public forums.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what will you do differently, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: We did not pay enough attention to how scared some women felt when rumours started. In the next two weeks I will talk to a few groups after market and write down the main worries I hear. I will count how many times people mention data theft or hidden fees. If I see that a message we use makes people more afraid, I will stop using it and keep the explanations that seem to calm them.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: We forgot to track how many women tried SokoLink once and then went back to business as usual. Over the next two weeks I will pull numbers on first-time versus repeat users and speak to at least ten women who dropped off. I will also count how often agents skip the consent explanation when they are busy. At the end of this period, we will stop pushing any activities that only give us registrations and keep the ones that lead to consistent use and clear consent.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: We treated every woman as just a data point and forgot that some are balancing many risks at once: politics, family, and debts. In the next two weeks I will sit with a small panel of women from different age groups and literacy levels and follow their real trading days, writing down every time SokoLink adds stress instead of reducing it. I will count how often they need help, how many times the network interrupts sales, and how many moments they feel they have no choice. As a team we will agree to stop any practice that relies on pressure or confusion and keep only those steps that women describe as making them feel safer and more in control.

question_text: In the next 30 days, what ideas do you want to test? What signs or proof would make you change your mind? What current activities will you stop or reduce so that you have time and energy to learn?
text: In the next 30 days I want to test doing smaller group talks under the trees instead of big market launches. If women still do not join after that, I will know we must change again. To create space, I will reduce some office-based planning meetings so that I can spend more time in the field.

question_text: In the next 30 days, what ideas do you want to test? What signs or proof would make you change your mind? What current activities will you stop or reduce so that you have time and energy to learn?
text: I want to test a weekly market feedback board where women can anonymously write what they like and dislike about SokoLink, and a simple SMS survey for agents. Proof that would shift my view is if the board shows repeated frustration around the same step or if agents report that certain features never get used. To protect learning time, I will reduce general awareness events in new districts and concentrate on deeper testing in two pilot markets.

question_text: In the next 30 days, what ideas do you want to test? What signs or proof would make you change your mind? What current activities will you stop or reduce so that you have time and energy to learn?
text: Over 30 days I will test a simple experiment: one market where we prioritise listening and slow iteration, and another where we push for numbers. In both, I will track trust indicators like repeat use, women asking questions, and rumours in our log. If the numbers-first market shows more fear and drop-out, I will change our whole rollout strategy to put learning and safety first. To make space, I will deliberately cancel non-essential presentations and insist that the core team spends that time reflecting with women and agents instead.

question_text: How will you treat these rumours as useful information, not just noise? Where and how will you listen, how will you collect this feedback, and how will it shape your next version of SokoLink?
text: I will ask agents to write down the rumours they hear during their rounds and share them in our weekly meeting. We will take note of the most frequent stories and add a section in our meetings to clarify them. When updating SokoLink messages, we will check that we respond to at least the top two rumours.

question_text: How will you treat these rumours as useful information, not just noise? Where and how will you listen, how will you collect this feedback, and how will it shape your next version of SokoLink?
text: I will organise short listening sessions after church or mosque and ask, “what are people saying about SokoLink?” without defending the project. We will record the rumours on cards and cluster them by theme such as data, fees, or politics. For the next version of SokoLink, we will test new scripts and icons that directly respond to these themes and then ask the same groups if the rumours have reduced.

question_text: How will you treat these rumours as useful information, not just noise? Where and how will you listen, how will you collect this feedback, and how will it shape your next version of SokoLink?
text: Instead of arguing against rumours, I will treat them as early warning signals that our design or behaviour is breaking trust. I will set up monthly ‘rumour mapping’ sessions where women, agents, and local leaders place stories on a big map showing where and why they spread. We will then use that map to redesign consent, receipts, and messages so they answer those fears head-on. In each new version release, we will clearly say which rumours we heard and what specific change we made in response.

question_text: In one market cycle, how will you sit with them, watch, and listen to understand their experience? How will you test changes together with them (not just design for them) and then adjust SokoLink based on what you learn?
text: During the next market cycle, I will schedule at least two visits where I sit at a stall and quietly observe. I will ask the women a few questions about what is easy and what is hard. If they mention a small change, I will take it back to the team for consideration.

question_text: In one market cycle, how will you sit with them, watch, and listen to understand their experience? How will you test changes together with them (not just design for them) and then adjust SokoLink based on what you learn?
text: For one full market cycle I will pick a group of about 15 women and follow them from opening to closing time on different days, writing down where SokoLink slows them down or worries them. At mid-cycle we will test one or two specific changes, like simplifying the menu or changing where receipts are printed, directly with this group and see if their speed and comfort improve. Based on those results we will update the design for all markets.

question_text: In one market cycle, how will you sit with them, watch, and listen to understand their experience? How will you test changes together with them (not just design for them) and then adjust SokoLink based on what you learn?
text: Across one market cycle I will create a small advisory circle of women traders that I sit with repeatedly at different times and weather conditions. Together we will mark on a timeline the moments when SokoLink helps, when it is neutral, and when it actually adds stress. Every time we introduce a tweak—like changing consent prompts or how receipts look—we will try it with them first and let them decide whether it should stay. Their judgments will directly shape what becomes standard in all other markets.

question_text: When you compare USSD with offline use and a small printer to a telco-only smartphone app, what does each option mean for who can use it, how well it works when the network fails, how costly it is for users, and how well it protects data, and which option do you choose for the next test and why?
text: USSD with a printer means even women with simple phones can use it, but it adds some extra steps. A telco smartphone app has nicer features but mainly helps those who already have data bundles. When the network fails, the app will be more affected. For the next test I would lean toward USSD but still keep an eye on the app option for the future.

question_text: When you compare USSD with offline use and a small printer to a telco-only smartphone app, what does each option mean for who can use it, how well it works when the network fails, how costly it is for users, and how well it protects data, and which option do you choose for the next test and why?
text: USSD plus a printer is more inclusive because it works on basic phones and lets us give printed proof when the network is unreliable. It might require some maintenance for printers but keeps costs away from users’ data bundles. A telco-only app gives quick analytics but locks us into one company and risks excluding older women. For the next test I would choose USSD with offline support as the main path, while documenting exactly where it struggles so we can improve it rather than jumping too fast to the app.

question_text: When you compare USSD with offline use and a small printer to a telco-only smartphone app, what does each option mean for who can use it, how well it works when the network fails, how costly it is for users, and how well it protects data, and which option do you choose for the next test and why?
text: USSD with offline capability and a printer distributes power: women keep paper records, basic phones stay valid, and data can be hosted under rules set by the partnership, not one telco. It also works in the very moments when a smartphone app would fail—heavy rain, power cuts, or exhausted bundles. The telco-only app concentrates data and decision-making in one corporate actor and risks turning women into passive data sources. For the next test, I would deepen the USSD path, not just for convenience, but because it better matches our values of inclusion, resilience, and shared governance of data.

question_text: How would you design a consent process for people who cannot read well, for example using a short Lusoga audio message and a clear way to say “no,” that still works offline and leaves a record that can be checked later when the data syncs?
text: I would prepare a short Lusoga audio explaining SokoLink and play it before registration. After that, the agent would ask if they agree and note yes or no on the paper form or phone. When the device connects again, those notes would be entered into the system.

question_text: How would you design a consent process for people who cannot read well, for example using a short Lusoga audio message and a clear way to say “no,” that still works offline and leaves a record that can be checked later when the data syncs?
text: My process would start with a simple Lusoga audio, played offline, that clearly says what SokoLink does and that saying no is allowed. Then the agent would ask one or two questions to check understanding. Consent would be captured either as a coded choice on the phone or as a mark on a numbered consent card. When the phone later syncs, that code would appear in the woman’s profile so we can verify that she was properly informed.

question_text: How would you design a consent process for people who cannot read well, for example using a short Lusoga audio message and a clear way to say “no,” that still works offline and leaves a record that can be checked later when the data syncs?
text: I would co-design the Lusoga consent audio with women themselves so it uses familiar examples, like how they share information in VSLAs. After playing it offline, the agent would ask the woman to choose between two clear options—yes or no—by pressing a simple USSD code, not just nodding. That choice would be stored locally with a unique consent ID also printed on her first receipt. When the device reconnects, both the consent choice and ID sync to the server so any future dispute can be checked against a verifiable record, including the date and agent who collected it.

question_text: If the network goes down again, what are the exact steps you will follow to record each transaction while offline, give the user proof, and then sync the data and update receipts when the network comes back?
text: If the network fails, we will switch to an agreed paper template and write all key details for each sale. The buyer and seller will both sign or thumbprint. When the network is back, we will enter these records into SokoLink and, if requested, give updated balances later.

question_text: If the network goes down again, what are the exact steps you will follow to record each transaction while offline, give the user proof, and then sync the data and update receipts when the network comes back?
text: My sequence would be: first, move into offline mode or paper slips that mirror the SokoLink fields. Second, issue a slip or stamp with a transaction number and amount to the woman, so she has proof in her hand. Third, at the end of the day, staff would enter those slip numbers into the system and reconcile totals. If there are mismatches, we would sit with the affected women to fix them before finalising the records.

question_text: If the network goes down again, what are the exact steps you will follow to record each transaction while offline, give the user proof, and then sync the data and update receipts when the network comes back?
text: When the network fails, we would not pause women’s business; instead, agents would use pre-numbered receipt books that capture the same details as SokoLink, and traders would get one copy immediately. Those numbers would be entered into the app once connectivity returns and marked as ‘offline-synced’ so they can be tracked separately. At the next market day, we would invite traders to compare their slips with what appears in their SokoLink history, turning reconciling into a joint exercise that deepens, rather than weakens, trust.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: If I notice a small mistake, I will report it to the data focal person and correct it. At the next group meeting, I will briefly mention that we found and fixed some errors and remind staff to cross-check entries before syncing.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: I would immediately inform the data manager and local partner and agree on how to correct the affected records. Then I would organise a short market briefing with those women to explain the mistake and show their corrected balances. Publicly, I would use the radio talk show to say that we discovered and fixed an error and have now added an extra review step before data is finalised.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: I will treat the mistake as a chance to practice accountability. First, I will inform the programme lead, IT team, and a representative group of traders whose data might be affected. Together we will agree how to correct the records and how to explain it clearly. Then, through radio and market meetings, we will share that the error was found, what exactly was done to fix it, and what new controls—like double-checks or restricted editing rights—have been put in place. We will also invite women to review their own statements and tell us if anything still looks wrong.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: I will use Prototype A in one market and Prototype B in the other and monitor how many traders sign up and how many complaints we get. If complaints are too many on one side, we may consider stopping that prototype. Otherwise we continue both for some time.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: For the test I would cap each prototype at about 50 women and 500 transactions a month to limit risk. Our targets would include error rates, user satisfaction, and how well each option handles network problems. If one prototype fails badly on any of these, we pause it and shift learning to the other. A surprising result like older women preferring the smartphone app would push me to explore why and adjust our assumptions about who benefits from which design.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: I would run a controlled pilot where each prototype is used by a comparable group of traders with clear caps on users and transaction volumes. We would predefine success metrics around trust, inclusion of low-literacy women, accuracy, and loan approvals based on the records. Stop rules would include any sign that a prototype systematically excludes certain women or creates unmanageable errors. If we see a surprising pattern—for example, that the supposedly ‘simple’ version actually confuses people more—we will not push it; instead, we will change direction and openly explain to partners why our plan has shifted.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: One idea is to use simple poster charts that show SokoLink steps with pictures instead of many words. I will display them near two stalls for one week and ask those traders if the pictures helped them remember the steps.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: I would set up a ‘practice corner’ at the end of the market row where women can try out mock SokoLink transactions without pressure. Over one week, I will record how many come, what questions they ask, and whether their error rates decline in real sales. If it helps, we will repeat this in more markets using the same simple set-up.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: My idea is to use storytelling circles: once a day, a small group of women gathers to share short stories of when SokoLink helped or hurt them, with a facilitator noting patterns on simple cards. In one week, we can see which obstacles come up again and again and quickly adjust training scripts or flow explanations. This costs almost nothing but can dramatically shift whose voices shape the tool.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: We will invite some market mamas and buyers to give comments on our proposed changes. In the session we will show them printed screenshots and ask if they agree. At the end we will have a list of their comments to share with developers.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: I will run a workshop where market mamas write down their pain points on cards and buyers do the same from their side. Then we will group these issues and, in mixed teams, propose changes to the flows or receipts. By the end, we will produce a simple, prioritised list of improvements plus sketches that show how a typical transaction should look in the new version.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: To make them co-designers, I would first meet women and buyers separately to hear what SokoLink feels like in their daily lives. Then we would bring them together around a big paper ‘journey’ of a sale and ask them to place green and red stickers at points that help or harm them. In groups they would then redraw a better journey and explain it back. We would leave with a community-agreed prototype of new steps, written in their language, which the tech team must use as the starting point.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, “we heard you, we changed,” and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: After the sprint I will prepare a simple message for radio stating that we collected feedback and made improvements. I will mention that SokoLink is now easier to use and that some steps are shorter, without going into much detail.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, “we heard you, we changed,” and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: My message will say, we heard you when you said the system was slow, the consent words were confusing, and receipts did not show all details. We changed by shortening key steps, rewriting consent in simpler Lusoga, and adding more information to receipts. I will highlight these three because they were the most common complaints and they directly affect women’s trust and daily use.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, “we heard you, we changed,” and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: I will write a message that starts with, many of you told us SokoLink was tiring, unclear, and sometimes frightening. We heard you, we changed. Then I will highlight three concrete shifts: we removed some unnecessary steps, we now explain consent in a short audio in local language, and we insist that printed receipts clearly show fees and loan terms. I will explain that these changes were chosen because they protect women’s dignity, understanding, and control over their data.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: In election season, leaders want to be seen, MTN wants more users, and buyers want steady supply. My red lines are that SokoLink should not be used for campaigning, women should not be forced to join, and fees should remain fair. I will ask that these points be written into the MoU.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: District leaders want quick wins, MTN wants to control the channel, brokers want deals, church leaders want moral protection, and buyers want reliable produce. My red lines are: no political use of women’s data, no partnership that cuts out basic-phone users, and no hidden fees. I will work with legal colleagues to translate these into concrete MoU clauses, with clear consequences if a partner breaks them.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: I see that some actors may try to soften consent language or push SokoLink to align with their political or commercial goals. My three red lines are: data must not be used to target or punish women, inclusion of low-connectivity women must remain a requirement, and community oversight must remain in the governance structure. I will insist that these appear as non-negotiable clauses in the MoU, with clear monitoring and a right to suspend the partnership if they are violated, so that during election heat we can point back to what we all signed.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a “facilitation,” what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: I will explain politely that we are not allowed to pay facilitation and suggest that we work through the official market committee instead. I will also brief my supervisor afterwards so the issue is on record.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a “facilitation,” what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: I would thank the leader for their support and clearly say that we cannot provide informal payments because it goes against our values and rules. I would offer public recognition or inclusion in official planning meetings as an alternative. After the meeting I will write a short note describing what was asked, who was present, and how I responded, and share it with my line manager so we have a consistent approach if the issue comes up again.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a “facilitation,” what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: I will respond calmly that, to protect both them and the traders, we cannot give informal facilitation and that we prefer everything to be done in the open through the market committee. I will emphasise how this keeps trust in their leadership as well. I will then document the request in our integrity log, notify the programme’s safeguarding or anti-fraud contact, and agree on a shared strategy for future interactions with that leader so we send one clear message while still involving them in constructive, transparent roles.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: I will ask that the link only shares information needed for fees and that women are told this in simple language. I will propose a clear statement in the MoU that the data must not be used for non-market purposes.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: I would propose that any integration is opt-in, that it only sends confirmation of fee payment rather than full transaction histories, and that women can question fees without losing access. These conditions and limits on data use would be written into the MoU and technical design, and a simple complaints channel would be set up so women can report abuse.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: I will insist that the integration is designed with a ‘minimum necessary data’ principle, with clear purpose, retention periods, and a ban on secondary use, all written in the MoU. Women must be able to pay fees outside SokoLink if they choose, and there must be a safe, independent channel to challenge errors. A small joint committee including women traders will periodically review the integration and can recommend changes or suspension if it starts to silence women or create fear.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: I will invite one staff member and one market woman who has used SokoLink to talk about their experience. They will repeat that SokoLink is safe and that fees are clear. Afterwards, I will visit markets and ask informally if people heard the show and feel more comfortable.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: On the show I would host a partner staff member, a respected woman trader, and a local religious leader. They would repeat three messages: women’s consent matters, SokoLink will not hide fees, and everyone has the right to ask questions. To see if trust grows, we will monitor whether more women sign up voluntarily, whether rumours in our feedback logs reduce, and whether fewer people ask to be removed from the system.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: My panel would be a mix of voices that people already trust: a market chairlady, a church or mosque leader, a buyer who respects fair deals, and a technical representative. They would keep returning to three points: your dignity and consent are more important than data or speed, fees and conditions must be open, and SokoLink is a tool for women, not for politicians or hidden interests. To measure trust, we will track changes in voluntary enrolment, continued use by those who previously wanted to drop out, and the tone of feedback in women’s groups and community meetings over several months, not just during the radio slot itself.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what will you do differently, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: We forgot to track how our choices affected the women who do not speak up loudly. In the next two weeks I will ask agents to record not only complaints but also who stays silent and walks away. I will count how many women leave the queue when there is a network issue and how many times consent is rushed. At the end, anything that increases silent drop-out we will stop or redesign, and we will keep the practices that keep women at the table and willing to ask questions.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: We forgot that learning is not just about system bugs but about people’s fears and hopes. For the next two weeks I will do daily short debrief circles with traders right after the market closes, writing down the three hardest and three easiest moments when using SokoLink. I will count patterns across those notes and compare them with our log of errors. We will stop any practice that repeatedly shows up as frightening or humiliating, even if it looks efficient on paper, and keep or strengthen the ones women describe as giving them voice and clarity.

question_text: In the next 30 days, what ideas do you want to test? What signs or proof would make you change your mind? What current activities will you stop or reduce so that you have time and energy to learn?
text: In the next 30 days I want to test pairing SokoLink training with VSLA meetings instead of stand-alone market demos. I will look for proof like higher sign-up from older members and fewer complaints about confusion. If those numbers do not move, I will stop that approach and try something else. To create space, I will reduce time spent on generic sensitisation tours and shift those hours into structured learning visits with VSLAs.

question_text: In the next 30 days, what ideas do you want to test? What signs or proof would make you change your mind? What current activities will you stop or reduce so that you have time and energy to learn?
text: I will run two parallel 30-day experiments: in one area we push fast expansion, in another we cap numbers and focus on deep feedback and redesign with women. I will track trust indicators, error rates, and loan approvals coming from each area. If the fast expansion zone shows more fear and weaker loan outcomes, I will argue that we redesign the whole rollout strategy around slower, deeper trials. To make room, I will stop chasing vanity indicators like total registrations and invest that staff time into listening sessions and joint reflection with women traders.

question_text: How will you treat these rumours as useful information, not just noise? Where and how will you listen, how will you collect this feedback, and how will it shape your next version of SokoLink?
text: I will treat each rumour as a clue to a design gap. We will collect them through a simple log at radio stations, in markets, and during VSLA meetings. Every two weeks the team will group rumours into themes and map them against system features. If many stories point to fear of hidden fees, we will adjust receipts and messages first, then check if that rumour fades in the next round of logs.

question_text: How will you treat these rumours as useful information, not just noise? Where and how will you listen, how will you collect this feedback, and how will it shape your next version of SokoLink?
text: I will invite women to become ‘rumour reporters’ in each market, using simple notebooks or voice notes to capture the stories they hear, who says them, and what they fear. Instead of dismissing the rumours, we will lay them out on the table at each design sprint and ask, what part of SokoLink might be feeding this story. Our next version will include at least three changes that directly answer those fears, and we will return to the markets saying, this rumour led to this specific change so that people see their concerns shaping the tool.

question_text: In one market cycle, how will you sit with them, watch, and listen to understand their experience? How will you test changes together with them (not just design for them) and then adjust SokoLink based on what you learn?
text: Over one market cycle I will join women on different days and times, including peak market and quiet moments, observing how they juggle SokoLink with other tasks. Mid-cycle, I will bring a few small tweaks, like a shorter code for common items, and test them in live trading with their permission. If those tweaks reduce waiting time and frustration, we will bake them into the main product and document how women’s suggestions directly shaped the change.

question_text: In one market cycle, how will you sit with them, watch, and listen to understand their experience? How will you test changes together with them (not just design for them) and then adjust SokoLink based on what you learn?
text: For a full market cycle I will treat the stalls as our main office. I will sit on low stools with women, take turns acting as customer and trader, and let them critique every step as we mimic real transactions. Together we will sketch alternative flows on scrap paper and test them immediately with actual buyers. At the end of the cycle, the adjustments that women say made the most difference to their dignity and speed will become the default design for all other markets.

question_text: When you compare USSD with offline use and a small printer to a telco-only smartphone app, what does each option mean for who can use it, how well it works when the network fails, how costly it is for users, and how well it protects data, and which option do you choose for the next test and why?
text: USSD with offline and a small printer gives reach to women with basic phones and keeps functioning in storms and at the edges of network coverage, though it forces us to manage printer paper and basic maintenance. A telco-only app gives smoother dashboards but depends on data bundles and locks us into one company’s rules about data. For the next test I choose USSD with offline because it keeps the door open for the poorest women and protects us from one-sided control over their transaction histories.

question_text: When you compare USSD with offline use and a small printer to a telco-only smartphone app, what does each option mean for who can use it, how well it works when the network fails, how costly it is for users, and how well it protects data, and which option do you choose for the next test and why?
text: USSD plus offline plus printers lets us respect three things at once: women’s mixed phone reality, the unreliability of networks, and the need for shared control over data. The telco-only app might look modern but shifts power away from women and local partners towards one company that can change terms later. For the next test I will defend USSD with offline as our main path and use its results to show partners that inclusion and resilience beat fancy interfaces when the goal is to build safe digital trails for loans.

question_text: How would you design a consent process for people who cannot read well, for example using a short Lusoga audio message and a clear way to say “no,” that still works offline and leaves a record that can be checked later when the data syncs?
text: I would create a short Lusoga audio clip that explains what SokoLink will do and that women are free to say yes or no without losing other services. After playing it offline, the agent would ask the woman to choose yes or no using a simple code like 1 or 2 or by signing a numbered consent card. That number would be linked to her profile and synced later, so we can always check when and how she agreed, or if she refused.

question_text: How would you design a consent process for people who cannot read well, for example using a short Lusoga audio message and a clear way to say “no,” that still works offline and leaves a record that can be checked later when the data syncs?
text: Consent would be a conversation, not just a button. We would co-create an offline Lusoga audio track where women explain to other women what SokoLink is and what saying yes or no really means. After listening, each woman would show her decision by choosing a clear symbol on a laminated card or pressing a simple USSD option that works without data. The agent would write or capture a consent code on her first receipt, and when the device syncs, that code and timestamp become part of a verifiable consent log that can be checked by women, auditors, and partners in future.

question_text: If the network goes down again, what are the exact steps you will follow to record each transaction while offline, give the user proof, and then sync the data and update receipts when the network comes back?
text: When the network fails, agents will immediately switch to pre-numbered carbon receipt books that mirror SokoLink fields. Each sale gets a unique number; one copy goes to the trader and one stays in the book. When connectivity returns, we will enter those numbers and amounts into SokoLink and mark them as offline entries. At the next visit we will invite traders to compare their paper slips with the digital record so they can confirm nothing was lost.

question_text: If the network goes down again, what are the exact steps you will follow to record each transaction while offline, give the user proof, and then sync the data and update receipts when the network comes back?
text: The moment the signal drops, we log the time and move into an agreed offline protocol: agents use numbered slips and stamp each with the trader’s ID and sale details, handing one copy to her. Later, when the network is back, we batch-upload these slips into SokoLink, tagging them as offline-synced and cross-checking totals with the duplicated receipt book. We then hold a short group session where women compare their slips to the updated digital balances so that they directly verify that their trading history survived the outage.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: If I find a mistake I will alert the data manager and local partner and identify which records are affected. We will correct the entries, then meet those traders to show the before and after. At the next radio show we will say clearly that an error was found and fixed and that we have added an extra review step so that two people must check key fields before syncing.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: I will treat a small mistake as a test of our honesty. I will inform the programme lead, IT team, and a group of elected women representatives, and show them exactly what went wrong and how we will correct it. Once corrections are made, we will explain on radio and in market meetings that the error existed, what it meant, and which new guardrails we have added, like audit logs and restricted editing. We will invite women to check their records and give them an easy way to report any remaining discrepancies.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: I would pick two similar markets, assign Prototype A to one and B to the other, and cap each at 50 traders and a fixed weekly transaction limit. Success would be measured by error rates, number of active women users after one month, and how many traders say they trust the receipts. We will stop any prototype that repeatedly fails these tests. If I see that the version we assumed was weaker actually builds more trust and inclusion, I will adjust the roadmap to favour it, even if it was not our original favourite.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: My test would limit both prototypes to a safe number of women and transactions and would be explicit that this is a learning phase, not a contest. We would set success measures around women’s perceived safety, inclusion of basic-phone users, and the quality of loan decisions built on each data stream. We would define stop rules if any prototype undermines consent or increases exclusion. A surprising result, like older women strongly preferring the more complex prototype because it gives better proof, would force us to revisit our assumptions and redesign around what trust actually looks like in their eyes, even if that complicates our tech plans.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: A low-cost idea is to schedule a daily 20-minute ‘slow line’ where an agent deliberately serves fewer women but explains every step and lets them practice pressing the keys themselves. For one week I will track how many of these women come back to the normal line and how many errors they still make. If their confidence and accuracy increase, we will repeat this pattern across more markets.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: I would ask each VSLA to nominate one ‘explain-in-our-words’ champion who translates SokoLink steps into local sayings and examples. For one week those champions will run five-minute teaching moments at the end of meetings, using only their voices and simple drawings in the sand or on paper. I will measure whether women from those groups use SokoLink more consistently and report fewer fears. If it works, these champions become a key part of our long-term inclusion model.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: I will organise a co-design session where market mamas and buyers map the journey of a typical sale on big paper. Each side will mark in red where SokoLink makes things harder and in green where it helps. In small groups they will then propose changes, which we will write into a clear list of ‘must-change now’ and ‘change later’ items. The final product will be a community-prioritised change log that guides the next release.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: I will set up several short, repeated design circles where women and buyers, in separate then joint sessions, role-play real buying and selling while we capture their frustrations on cards. They will then rearrange those cards into a new ideal flow and agree on which steps are non-negotiable for safety and fairness. The concrete output will be a set of hand-drawn but precise screens and paper slips that reflect their agreed journey, which we commit to building and then bringing back for another round of testing.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, “we heard you, we changed,” and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: I will write a short message that starts with, you told us SokoLink was too long, too confusing, and not clear about data. We heard you, we changed. Then I will highlight three changes: fewer steps for small sales, a clearer consent explanation, and receipts that show all charges. These three respond directly to the top concerns raised in feedback meetings.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, “we heard you, we changed,” and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: My public message will name specific voices, for example, many market mamas in Iganga told us the code was tiring, consent was unclear, and they feared hidden fees. We heard you, we changed. I will highlight that we simplified the code for everyday sales, recorded a new consent audio in Lusoga, and redesigned receipts to show all fees openly. I will explain that these changes came directly from their stories and invite them to check if we kept our word.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: During elections, district leaders want quick visible wins, MTN wants exclusive deals, brokers want side payments, church leaders want to keep dignity, buyers want reliable supplies, and police want calm. My red lines are that SokoLink data cannot be used for political targeting, basic-phone users cannot be excluded, and consent language cannot be weakened. I will push for these to appear as explicit clauses in the MoU, with clear sanctions if any partner violates them.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: I see that some actors will push us to trade away consent language or inclusion to get quick signatures before elections. My red lines are that women’s consent must remain explicit and strong, alternative access for low-connectivity users must be guaranteed, and community oversight cannot be removed. I will work with legal colleagues to turn these into MoU articles with monitoring and a right to suspend the agreement if they are breached, so that our non-negotiables are not just slogans but enforceable commitments.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a “facilitation,” what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: If a leader hints at facilitation, I will calmly repeat that our rules do not allow personal payments and suggest that any support must be in-kind and transparent, like training for all traders. I will document the request with date and details and share it with my manager so we can respond consistently. I will then make an effort to include that leader in open forums where we publicly appreciate their role, so they do not feel ignored even though we said no.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a “facilitation,” what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: I will say clearly that we cannot pay any private facilitation because it would undermine the trust women have in both the leader and SokoLink. I will offer other ways to recognise their contribution, such as co-hosting official learning events. Right after the meeting I will write a factual note about what was asked and how I responded and share it with the programme’s safeguarding or anti-fraud focal person. Together we will plan future engagements with that leader so the message stays consistent and the relationship remains respectful but clean.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: I will propose that SokoLink only shares the bare minimum needed to confirm fee payment, that women are informed and can opt out, and that traders who complain about fees will not be blocked from the platform. These conditions will be written in the MoU, along with a clear list of prohibited uses, such as using fee data to track political loyalties.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: I will insist that any link is governed by rules which say what data can move, for what purpose, for how long, and under whose oversight. Women should still be able to question a fee and pay through other channels without fear of punishment. A joint committee including women’s representatives will periodically review the integration, and the MoU will include the right to suspend data sharing if complaints or fear increase. This stops the link from quietly turning SokoLink into a tool that disciplines women instead of serving them.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: I will invite a project staff member, a well-known woman trader, and a church leader. They will repeat three messages: your data will not be shared without consent, fees will be openly displayed, and women can say no and still be respected. To check if trust is growing we will monitor whether more women join voluntarily, whether fewer people request to be removed, and whether rumours in market meetings start to reduce.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: My radio panel will include a respected market chairlady, a faith leader, a buyer, and one technical representative, so that listeners hear from people they already know. They will repeat three simple messages in every show: women’s consent is required, fees and conditions are not secrets, and SokoLink exists to strengthen women’s trading power, not to control them. To see if trust is really rebuilding we will track the mix of women enrolling, ask focus groups if they feel safer using SokoLink, and read our rumour logs over time to see if fear-based stories are declining, not only count radio calls.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what will you do differently, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: Honestly I do not think we got much wrong, people just need more time to adapt. In the next two weeks I will mostly push the same approach harder and hope that the complaints reduce as everyone gets used to SokoLink.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what will you do differently, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: We probably only forgot to explain that SokoLink is from good organisations, but otherwise the plan was fine. I do not plan big changes, just more sensitisation, and I will assume the system is okay unless there is a very big crisis.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what will you do differently, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: I think the main mistake was that women did not listen carefully. In the next two weeks I will repeat the same messages more loudly on market days and not really change the design or the way we are rolling out.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what will you do differently, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: We underestimated how worried some women would be about their data. In the next two weeks I will ask agents to write down the main questions they get and count how many times rumours come up. If a certain explanation seems to confuse people we will stop using that line and keep the words that work better.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what will you do differently, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: We forgot to plan enough time for older women to practice slowly. Over the next two weeks I will schedule more short demos at quieter hours and count how many older traders attend and complete a transaction. If few come, we will stop doing them at that time and try moments that fit them better.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what will you do differently, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: We forgot that the rainy season affects network and movement. In the next two weeks I will track on which days the system fails most and how many transactions are lost. If we see a pattern, we will stop scheduling busy sign ups during those hours and keep activities when the service is more stable.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what will you do differently, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: We treated all complaints as noise instead of data. For the next two weeks I will set up a simple sheet where every agent records three things each day: failed transactions, women who walked away, and top questions asked. After two weeks we will stop any activity that consistently appears next to walk-aways and keep or adjust the ones that lead to repeat use.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what will you do differently, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: We forgot to compare how basic phone users and smartphone users are experiencing SokoLink. Over the next two weeks I will count separate error rates and drop-outs for each group and ask both groups why they stay or leave. If a feature only works for one group we will pause it and redesign so it does not push the others out.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what will you do differently, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: We forgot to check if women actually understand the loan story behind SokoLink or just click through. For two weeks I will sample women after transactions and ask them to explain in their own words what data is stored and why. I will count how many can answer clearly. If most cannot, we will stop rushing through consent and build in a slower, clearer step even if it takes more time.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what will you do differently, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: We forgot that for many women this is not a tech problem but a trust and power problem. In the next two weeks I will sit with the groups who were most suspicious and ask them what exactly feels risky or unfair. I will count which fears show up most, compare that with where errors happen, and then stop any practice that increases fear even if it looks efficient to us, keeping only the pieces that women themselves say feel safe and useful.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what will you do differently, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: We forgot to make space for women to say no to parts of the design, not just to joining. Over two weeks I will run short listening circles where women map the steps they like and the ones they would remove if they were in charge. I will count which steps they mark in red. Our team will stop forcing any red step that is not legally required and keep or strengthen the green ones, even if it means redoing our workplan.

question_text: What did we get wrong or forget? In the next two weeks, what will you do differently, what exactly will you check or count, and how will you decide what to stop and what to keep doing?
text: We forgot that pilots should feel like experiments where women teach us, not like mini rollouts with fixed answers. In the next two weeks I will treat each market day as a test, ask women what to change tomorrow, and track which adjustments reduce confusion and rumour. Anything that repeatedly shows up as harmful or useless will be stopped, and we will openly tell women which ideas we kept because they came from them.

question_text: In the next 30 days, what ideas do you want to test? What signs or proof would make you change your mind? What current activities will you stop or reduce so that you have time and energy to learn?
text: In the next month I mostly want to stabilise what we already have, not test new ideas. If the numbers go up, I will assume things are fine, and I do not plan to stop any current activities to create extra learning time.

question_text: In the next 30 days, what ideas do you want to test? What signs or proof would make you change your mind? What current activities will you stop or reduce so that you have time and energy to learn?
text: I do not have specific experiments in mind. My goal for the next 30 days is just to reach the targets by pushing more registrations and answering rumours as they appear. I will keep all current activities running at the same level.

question_text: In the next 30 days, what ideas do you want to test? What signs or proof would make you change your mind? What current activities will you stop or reduce so that you have time and energy to learn?
text: I think the plan is already strong so I prefer not to test too many new ideas. Even if some things do not work perfectly we can just manage them on the way and still continue with our normal outreach schedule.

question_text: In the next 30 days, what ideas do you want to test? What signs or proof would make you change your mind? What current activities will you stop or reduce so that you have time and energy to learn?
text: In the next 30 days I want to test doing more small-group training using real examples from the market. If I see that women still do not understand after these sessions, that will be a sign to change the method. I will reduce some office-based reporting time so I can actually attend those groups in person.

question_text: In the next 30 days, what ideas do you want to test? What signs or proof would make you change your mind? What current activities will you stop or reduce so that you have time and energy to learn?
text: I would like to test sending short follow-up messages through VSLA leaders instead of only through agents. If feedback shows women still feel lost, I will know we must adjust again. To free time I will cut down on some routine meetings that do not add much value.

question_text: In the next 30 days, what ideas do you want to test? What signs or proof would make you change your mind? What current activities will you stop or reduce so that you have time and energy to learn?
text: I want to test holding joint feedback sessions with women and agents at the end of market day once a week. If we still hear the same complaints after a month, that will show we need a different strategy. I will reduce some field visits to non-pilot areas so that I can focus on these two pilot markets first.

question_text: In the next 30 days, what ideas do you want to test? What signs or proof would make you change your mind? What current activities will you stop or reduce so that you have time and energy to learn?
text: In 30 days I want to test whether giving women simple weekly summaries of their transactions increases their sense of control. Evidence that would change my mind is if we see no improvement in trust or usage despite this effort. I will stop doing broad awareness events that mainly generate one-day excitement and instead spend that time analysing what the weekly summaries are actually changing.

text: My process would be to play a short recorded message, then ask them if they agree and record their answer with a simple yes or no option on the handset. When the data syncs, those yes or no answers will be visible in the system.

question_text: How would you design a consent process for people who cannot read well, for example using a short Lusoga audio message and a clear way to say 'no', that still works offline and leaves a record that can be checked later when the data syncs?
text: I will ensure there is a clear yes or no question after the Lusoga audio, and the agent will select the response on the phone. The offline record of that choice will sync later so we know who agreed.

After playing it offline, the agent would ask two check questions to see if they understood and then record consent with a yes or no code that is stored locally. When the phone connects, those codes sync so we can later prove that people actually agreed or refused.

question_text: How would you design a consent process for people who cannot read well, for example using a short Lusoga audio message and a clear way to say 'no', that still works offline and leaves a record that can be checked later when the data syncs?

The agent plays a Lusoga audio track from the phone, then the person presses 1 for yes or 2 for no on a USSD screen or points to a card with these options. The agent records this on the handset with a timestamp. When the network returns, these records sync and form part of the audit trail.

question_text: How would you design a consent process for people who cannot read well, for example using a short Lusoga audio message and a clear way to say 'no', that still works offline and leaves a record that can be checked later when the data syncs?
text: To protect low-literacy users, I will couple a Lusoga audio with a simple choice screen and a paper consent card with a unique number. The agent marks their decision on the phone and on the card. Later, when the device syncs, the system will store both the answer and the consent number so we can cross-check it if there is a complaint.

question_text: How would you design a consent process for people who cannot read well, for example using a short Lusoga audio message and a clear way to say 'no', that still works offline and leaves a record that can be checked later when the data syncs?
text: I would co-create the consent message with women so it uses their images and fears. The process would be: listen to an offline Lusoga audio, answer two simple comprehension questions, and then choose yes or no using a very simple input like pressing one key. That decision would be stored locally alongside a consent ID and printed on their first receipt. When data syncs, we will have a verifiable trail that links each transaction history to a clear consent choice that can be reviewed later.

question_text: How would you design a consent process for people who cannot read well, for example using a short Lusoga audio message and a clear way to say 'no', that still works offline and leaves a record that can be checked later when the data syncs?
text: Consent should feel like a conversation, not a test. So we will use Lusoga audio plus a chance for women to repeat back key points in their own words. Only after they show they understand will they choose yes or no using a simple offline method that leaves a digital and paper trace. This way, when the data syncs, we know that the record of consent is both informed and checkable later.

question_text: How would you design a consent process for people who cannot read well, for example using a short Lusoga audio message and a clear way to say 'no', that still works offline and leaves a record that can be checked later when the data syncs?
text: I will design consent around dignity. The Lusoga audio will clearly state that saying no is allowed and explain how to withdraw later. After listening, women will make their choice via a simple symbol-based interface or by marking a card that matches a code in the phone. When the device syncs, we will have time-stamped evidence of when and how each woman gave or refused consent, which we can show back to them if they ever want to review it.
