text: My steps will be to immediately switch to offline recording using pre-numbered slips. Each trader will receive one copy of the slip with details of the sale while we keep the second copy. When the network is back we will capture each slip into SokoLink and cross-check totals at the end of the day.

question_text: If the network goes down again, what are the exact steps you will follow to record each transaction while offline, give the user proof, and then sync the data and update receipts when the network comes back?
text: When the network fails, agents will start using a simple offline form and issue signed receipts to traders so they have proof. After connectivity returns we will enter these records into the system, compare the numbers with the paper forms, and share updated statements with the women if they request.

question_text: If the network goes down again, what are the exact steps you will follow to record each transaction while offline, give the user proof, and then sync the data and update receipts when the network comes back?
text: In a network outage I will shift to an offline queue where each sale is written on a numbered receipt. The trader leaves with her copy, and later the numbers are entered in SokoLink. A quick reconciliation at the end of the day will help us fix any gaps before they cause mistrust.

question_text: If the network goes down again, what are the exact steps you will follow to record each transaction while offline, give the user proof, and then sync the data and update receipts when the network comes back?
text: I will treat the outage as part of normal life. Agents will have a clear offline playbook: record each sale on a duplicate slip, give one to the trader as immediate proof, and store the other for later entry. When the network returns, we will sync every offline sale into SokoLink, mark them as such, and invite traders to compare their slips with their digital balances so they see that their history was protected, not erased, by the outage plan.

question_text: If the network goes down again, what are the exact steps you will follow to record each transaction while offline, give the user proof, and then sync the data and update receipts when the network comes back?
text: First step: immediately note the moment the network fails and move into our offline mode where every sale is captured on a triplicate receipt. Second step: give women their copy so they can verify later. Third step: when connectivity returns, batch-upload these into SokoLink and generate a summary slip showing their updated totals. Finally, we hold a brief after-market session to check that women’s paper and digital records match, building trust through joint verification.

question_text: If the network goes down again, what are the exact steps you will follow to record each transaction while offline, give the user proof, and then sync the data and update receipts when the network comes back?
text: Our offline protocol will be simple and transparent: for every sale we write a record, give a stamped copy to the woman, and mark it as pending in a manual log. Later, we enter each into SokoLink and produce a short statement that shows which sales came from offline mode. Women can cross-check this, so the system proves it protects their history even when the signal disappears.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: If it is only a small mistake I will quietly correct it in the system and avoid telling traders or partners, because talking about errors might reduce trust in SokoLink.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: I would correct the mistake and not make a big deal out of it, since highlighting it in public could create unnecessary panic among women and authorities.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: For a small data error I think it is better to fix it internally and move on quickly, without informing many people outside the core team.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: If I find a mistake I will inform my supervisor and the data focal person so they can correct it. At the next opportunity I will mention to the group that there was a small issue but it has been fixed and encourage more careful data entry.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: I will tell the project manager about the error, work with IT to adjust the numbers, and then briefly inform the affected traders that their balances were updated. We will remind staff to double-check certain fields before saving data.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: I will notify the responsible data team and ask them to fix the mistake, then in the next community meeting I will simply say that we corrected some records and encourage people to report any doubts they have about their own data.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: If I notice a recording error I will share it with the programme lead and data manager, identify the affected accounts, and correct them. I will also explain to the traders involved what went wrong and what has been fixed. Publicly, I will say that we found and corrected an error and have added a second check before data is approved.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: I will inform both the technical and community engagement teams so we can handle it together. After fixing the data, we will tell the group that a mistake was made, how it was corrected, and what new checks we have introduced, such as having another person review key changes before they are final.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: I would see it as a prompt to strengthen our process. I will inform the core team, correct the mistake after confirming with the trader, and share a simple explanation in the next radio segment that errors can happen and how we deal with them. We will then add an extra step in the workflow to catch similar mistakes earlier.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: I will immediately tell the programme lead, data manager, and a few elected trader representatives about the mistake, however small. We will agree together how to correct it and then communicate openly in the market and on radio about what happened and how we fixed it. We will also add stronger controls, like clear logs of who changed what and simple tools for women to check their records, so that next time an error is more likely to be spotted by the women themselves.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: I would see this as a chance to show that our promise of transparency is real. I will inform both partners and women’s leaders, show them the nature and size of the error, correct it in front of them, and publicly explain the changes made to prevent a repeat. We will adjust our procedures and training and then invite more eyes on the system, not fewer, so that women feel empowered to challenge any future problems.

question_text: If you find a small mistake in how data was recorded, who will you inform, what will you share publicly, and what will you change so that this kind of mistake does not happen again?
text: I will notify the full leadership of the project, including community representatives, and present a short incident note that describes the mistake honestly. We will correct the data in collaboration with affected women and then issue a simple public statement saying that we discovered and fixed an error and what extra safeguards we have added. In this way, women learn that the system belongs to them and that their right to accurate data is taken seriously.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: I would roll out both prototypes widely and see what happens without putting many limits. If serious complaints arrive we can think about changes later, but otherwise I would just continue using whichever feels easier for staff.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: I think we can just place Prototype A in one market and B in another and allow all interested traders to join. I do not plan fixed stop rules; if partners like one version more, we will choose that one.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: For me it is enough to watch which prototype seems more popular and then move with that. I would not spend time writing strict success metrics or volume limits.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: I would put Prototype A in market one and Prototype B in market two and check which one gets fewer complaints after a month. If we see that one creates many issues we can stop it and continue the other. That will guide our plan.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: In two similar markets I will test each prototype and compare how many traders sign up and say they like it. If one clearly performs worse or causes confusion, I will recommend stopping that one and scaling the better version.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: The test will basically look at the number of transactions and simple feedback forms from each prototype market. If one prototype keeps failing or people complain a lot, we will stop it and keep the other, without making the design too complicated.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: I will design a controlled test where each prototype is used in only one market with a capped number of traders and transactions. We will set success criteria such as low error rates, high user satisfaction, and stable usage after the first weeks. If any prototype crosses an agreed red line, like many unresolved errors, we stop it and shift our efforts to the other.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: Each market will host one prototype, with firm limits to avoid harm: for example, 50 traders and a fixed maximum value of goods processed. We will track error rates, trust levels, and loan approvals. If we see surprising strengths in the prototype we thought was weaker, we will be ready to change our plan and invest more in improving it.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: I will predefine what good looks like for each prototype, for example, maximum 2 percent record errors and a majority of traders saying they feel safer using SokoLink. If a prototype fails these criteria or excludes basic-phone women, we will stop it. A surprising positive result from the ‘simpler’ solution could convince me to adopt that path instead of a more high-tech option.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: I will run a carefully bounded experiment where both prototypes are tested with comparable groups and clear red lines around trust, inclusion, and fairness. We will agree ahead of time that if a prototype hurts the most vulnerable traders, it stops, even if its numbers look good. A surprising finding, such as women trusting the low-tech prototype much more, would make me pivot the strategy toward that design and push partners to follow the evidence, not their tech preferences.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: My test will acknowledge that we are learning, not running a beauty contest. I will define what matters most – inclusion of low-literacy women, robustness during outages, and trust – and set stop rules if either prototype fails badly on those points. If results show that the prototype with fewer features actually builds more trust and better loan decisions, I will advocate for shifting resources to it and explain this clearly to all partners.

question_text: How would you design a test in two markets that compares Prototype A and Prototype B, including limits on volume, clear success targets, and rules for when to stop or continue, and what kind of surprising result would make you change your plan and how?
text: I will frame the test as a joint decision with women traders. We will agree together on signs of success and danger, like when the system feels too risky or when women are clearly excluded. If a prototype breaks those community-defined rules, we stop it, no matter what the partner prefers. An unexpected pattern, like older women strongly preferring one design, will be enough for me to push for a new direction grounded in their lived experience.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: I do not have a specific idea and think inclusion will just improve with time as people see benefits, so I do not plan a special one-week test.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: For now I prefer to focus on the main rollout rather than low-cost inclusion experiments, so I would not run a separate test in the coming week.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: I think we should keep things simple and not add new activities, so I would not test any inclusion-specific ideas this week beyond our usual awareness sessions.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: A small idea is to use existing VSLA meetings to explain SokoLink slowly to those who missed earlier demos. I will do this in one group next week and see if more of those members sign up afterwards.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: I can ask agents to set aside a short time each day only for older or shy women to practice with them. I will test this in one market for a week and check whether these women feel more comfortable using the system afterwards.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: We could create simple name tags for volunteer helpers in the market who other women can approach when stuck. In one week I will count how many traders seek help from them and whether that reduces basic errors.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: One low-cost idea is to pair first-time users with more experienced users from their own VSLA during their first market day. I will test this next week and track whether the paired women complete more successful transactions and report feeling less afraid than those without a buddy.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: I will design a one-week trial of evening debrief circles where women can ask any question about SokoLink without worrying about holding up customers. We will see whether joining these circles leads to higher use of the system and fewer rumours among the participants.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: A cheap idea is to use local languages and role plays to demonstrate SokoLink at church or mosque gatherings. I will test this in one community next week and observe if more low-literacy women join SokoLink in the following days compared to nearby areas without this activity.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: I would ask women to design and lead their own short SokoLink practice games using stones, beans, and paper so that anyone can join without a phone. In one week we can see whether women who attend those games feel more confident trying the real system. If yes, we will treat this as a core part of onboarding rather than a side activity.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: My low-cost idea is to appoint one trusted woman in each market as a 'SokoLink translator' whose job is to explain the tool in daily language to those who are unsure. I will test this role in one market for a week and measure whether new or fearful users are more likely to try at least one transaction when she is present.

question_text: What is one low-cost idea that can improve inclusion without buying new equipment, and how will you test this idea in one week?
text: I would invite women who feel excluded to co-create a list of small changes that would make them feel more welcome, and choose one that costs almost nothing, such as changing the order of messages. I will test this one change for a week and let them judge whether it made a difference, then repeat the cycle with their next suggestion.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: I think the technical team should design the next version and then show it to market mamas and buyers only when it is ready. Their job will mainly be to adopt it, not to design it with us.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: We will not involve traders deeply in the design because that can slow us down. Instead we will present the updated system and ask them to follow the new instructions.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: I prefer to let the experts decide the next version of SokoLink and only gather users to inform them about features, not to work with them on the design.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: We will invite a few market mamas and buyers to a feedback meeting, show them proposed changes, and ask what they think. At the end we will have a list of comments and suggestions that the developers can consider.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: I will organise a joint session where we present new ideas on flipcharts, then ask market mamas and buyers for their reactions. We will write down all their points and send them as inputs to the design team.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: We will consult traders and buyers using group discussions about what they like and dislike, but the detailed design will remain in the hands of technical staff. The main output will be a summary report of their views.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: I will run a design workshop where market mamas and buyers walk through the current steps and place coloured cards at points they find hard or risky. Together we will brainstorm alternative steps and agree on a short list of changes. The final product will be a prioritised change list that the development team uses as a roadmap.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: We will bring together traders and buyers in small groups, act out real selling situations, and ask them where SokoLink helps and where it gets in the way. They will then suggest adjustments, which we will capture in simple sketches and notes and use to brief the product team.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: My approach is to use journey mapping with market mamas and buyers. We will draw the full path from harvest to payment and let them mark pain points. The session will end with a agreed set of must-fix items and concrete suggestions for how SokoLink should change.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: I will treat market mamas and buyers as co-designers. In practical terms, that means spending sessions where they re-draw SokoLink on big sheets of paper, rearranging steps and even removing some. The end product will not be a consultant’s report but their own hand-drawn flows which we commit to translate into the next version of the system.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: We will hold separate design conversations with women and buyers first, to allow honest discussion, and then bring them together to negotiate a shared future flow. The session will use role play, drawing, and voting so that everyone participates. The output will be an agreed community design that we feed straight into development and then bring back to them for validation.

question_text: How will you work together with market mamas and buyers so that they help design the next version of SokoLink, and what exactly will you do in the session and produce at the end?
text: I will structure sessions where market women and buyers design their own 'ideal SokoLink' in small teams, using cardboard phones and fake receipts. We will compare these designs and pick elements that protect women and satisfy buyers. At the end we will have a set of community-owned design principles and example screens that we use as the baseline, not just as suggestions.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, 'we heard you, we changed,' and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: After the sprint I will simply say that we improved the system and encourage people to keep using it. I do not think it is necessary to mention specific feedback or changes.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, 'we heard you, we changed,' and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: I would release a general statement that SokoLink is now better and more reliable, without going into details about what people complained about or what we changed.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, 'we heard you, we changed,' and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: Our message will focus on promoting SokoLink, not on past problems. So I will not emphasise what we heard or what exactly we changed.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, 'we heard you, we changed,' and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: I will say that we listened to feedback and improved SokoLink to be easier and safer. I will briefly mention that some steps are shorter and that we tried to explain data use better.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, 'we heard you, we changed,' and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: My message will be short: we heard your concerns and we made SokoLink simpler, more reliable, and more transparent. I will not go into too much detail but I will indicate that these areas were improved.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, 'we heard you, we changed,' and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: I will record a radio spot stating that we have listened and made changes to the system, such as reducing steps and adjusting messages. The main goal will be to restore confidence in SokoLink.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, 'we heard you, we changed,' and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: My message will clearly say, you told us SokoLink was long, confusing, and not clear on data. We heard you, we changed. I will highlight that we shortened key steps, improved the consent explanation, and made receipts clearer because these address the main pain points we heard.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, 'we heard you, we changed,' and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: I will use radio and posters to say, we heard you when you complained about slow steps, unclear fees, and rumours about data. We changed by simplifying the flow, showing all fees on receipts, and adding clear consent messages. These three will be highlighted because they came up most in feedback sessions.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, 'we heard you, we changed,' and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: In my message I will quote the community, for example, you said the code was too long and the charges were unclear. Then I will say we heard you, we changed and name three specific improvements: shorter menus, transparent receipts, and a better explanation of who sees the data.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, 'we heard you, we changed,' and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: I will craft a public message that begins with the real complaints we heard, such as, you told us you felt rushed, you could not see your fees, and you feared your data was being misused. Then I will say, we heard you, we changed and point to three visible changes that answer these: slower, clearer consent, receipts with all charges, and options for basic phones. I will make sure people know that these came from their voices, not ours.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, 'we heard you, we changed,' and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: My message will be grounded in humility. I will openly admit that some parts of SokoLink made life harder, not easier, and then say, we heard you, we changed. I will highlight changes chosen by women themselves, for example, clearer fee information, stronger consent language, and protections for basic-phone users, explaining why each change matters for their dignity and control.

question_text: After the sprint, how will you write a short public message saying, 'we heard you, we changed,' and which three changes will you highlight and why?
text: I will ensure our radio talk and posters show the before and after clearly: this is what we used to do, this is what you asked for, and this is what changed. We will highlight three concrete shifts that women can see in their daily lives and invite them to test if our 'we heard you' is true by trying the new version and telling us again what still needs to change.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: During elections everyone is under pressure, so to keep things moving I would try to satisfy the main requests from officials and the telco, even if it means adjusting some of our conditions in the MoU.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: I do not think we should insist too much on red lines in an election period because that might delay approvals. It may be better to keep the MoU flexible and sort out issues later.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: Given the tensions of elections, I would choose not to push many conditions and instead allow officials and partners to frame most of the MoU content so that SokoLink is accepted quickly.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: District leaders want visibility, MTN wants more customers, brokers want quick gains, church leaders want values protected, buyers want reliable supply, and police want calm. My red lines are no direct political campaigning using SokoLink, no forced participation, and no selling of women’s data. I will ask that these be included in the MoU language.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: I see that leaders want to look good, companies want profit, and women want safety. I will insist that the MoU states clearly that data cannot be used for campaigns, that women must give consent, and that charges stay fair.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: My red lines are that SokoLink should not be used to threaten anyone, that people are not punished for refusing, and that no one changes data for political reasons. I will make sure these points are present in some form in the MoU.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: District leaders want quick wins, MTN wants control of the digital rails, brokers want side payments, church leaders want dignity, buyers want volume and quality, and police want order. My red lines are: SokoLink data cannot be used for policing or politics, women must have clear opt-out options, and basic-phone users cannot be locked out. I will push to translate these into concrete clauses in the MoU that mention sanctions if they are broken.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: During elections everyone’s incentives sharpen, so I will be very clear that our red lines are strong consent language, non-discrimination against low-tech users, and zero tolerance for political misuse. I will insist that all three are captured in writing in the MoU with monitoring roles and clear consequences if violated.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: I will read the political mood carefully and see that some actors might push us to water down protections. My non-negotiables are that women’s data cannot be shared beyond agreed uses, that SokoLink is not tied to one telco, and that women cannot be forced into it. I will work with legal colleagues to lock these into the MoU text.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: I see a mix of power and fear around SokoLink in an election season. My red lines are that women’s consent language will not be softened, that SokoLink will not become a tool of surveillance or vote-buying, and that access for the poorest women is protected. I will insist that these appear as explicit MoU articles drafted with legal and community input, so that we can point back to them when pressure to compromise rises.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: Knowing that elections can twist good tools into weapons, I will name our three red lines early: women’s data cannot be used to track political support, basic-phone women must stay fully included, and any partner that breaks these rules can lose access. I will work to embed these points clearly in the MoU, including who checks them and what happens if a partner crosses them.

question_text: When you look at the main actors (district leaders, MTN, brokers, church leaders, buyers, police) during election season, what does each one want, what are three things you will not cross (red lines), and how will you make sure these are clearly written into the MoU?
text: I will map each actor’s interests and fears with women in the room and use that to shape a MoU that protects them. Our red lines will reflect women’s priorities: no political spying, no exclusion because of phone type, and no weakening of safety language. These will be written into the agreement in plain language and repeated in public so that any attempt to cross them is visible.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a 'facilitation,' what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: If a leader asks for facilitation I might quietly provide a small token so that the project is not blocked, especially if that is common practice in the area.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a 'facilitation,' what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: I would consider giving a small unofficial facilitation to keep the relationship smooth, as long as it is not too large or too visible.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a 'facilitation,' what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: To avoid conflict I might ask colleagues to contribute a little for the leader so that they remain supportive, without documenting it formally.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a 'facilitation,' what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: I will politely explain that our organisation does not allow such facilitation payments and suggest we work through official procedures instead. I will inform my supervisor that this request was made so we can watch the situation.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a 'facilitation,' what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: I will decline the request and say that all our support must follow the project budget. Then I will make a short note about the conversation and share it with my line manager, so there is a record in case of any future misunderstanding.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a 'facilitation,' what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: I will gently but clearly say that I cannot offer personal facilitation and that I value working with them transparently. I will then report the incident through the normal internal channels so that others are aware.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a 'facilitation,' what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: I will say no respectfully, explain our code of conduct, and offer to explore legitimate ways to support the market, such as training for all traders. I will document the request in writing, including the date and context, and share it with my supervisor so we have a record while still keeping communication with the leader open.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a 'facilitation,' what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: I will decline calmly and steer the conversation toward official collaboration, for example inviting them to co-chair public meetings. Immediately after I will write down what was said and send it to our management so they can advise on further engagement with that leader.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a 'facilitation,' what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: I would respond by saying we cannot make private payments but are happy to discuss transparent support for the whole market. I will then log the request through our safeguarding system, so if similar issues happen we can respond consistently while still inviting the leader to public events.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a 'facilitation,' what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: I will clearly say no and explain that paying facilitation would damage trust in both SokoLink and the leader. I will record the incident in our integrity log and share it with senior staff and, where appropriate, community representatives. Then I will seek ways to honour the leader’s role publicly, like recognising them in official meetings, so that we maintain respect without crossing ethical lines.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a 'facilitation,' what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: My steps will be to say no politely but firmly, to document the request factually, and to share it through our anti-fraud channels. I will also talk with colleagues about how to keep engaging this leader in transparent roles, for example as part of open planning sessions, so that the relationship is based on shared goals, not hidden payments.

question_text: If a market leader hints that they want a 'facilitation,' what steps will you take to say no, record what happened, and still protect the relationship and the program?
text: I will respond that SokoLink is meant to reduce hidden payments, not create new ones, and explain that, to protect everyone, we must keep money flows open and documented. I will then record the incident, report it, and work with leadership to plan future interactions with that leader that are strictly public and accountable.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: If the district wants full linkage to their fee system, I would agree quickly to show cooperation, without spending too much time on detailed safeguards or limits on data use.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: I think sharing all transaction data with the district would be fine as long as they promise to use it for fees. We can trust them without putting many restrictions in writing.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: To maintain a good relationship I would mostly accept the district’s conditions on data sharing and not insist too heavily on limits that could slow the integration.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: I will ask that only necessary information for fees is shared and that it is kept confidential. We will also tell women that such sharing is happening and write this in the MoU.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: I would request that the link is not used for anything beyond fee collection and that women are informed about it. These points will be mentioned as basic safeguards in the agreement.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: My main safeguard will be to insist that the district keeps this data secure and does not publish individual information. We will include a general data protection clause in the MoU.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: I will propose minimal data sharing, limited to confirming that a fee is paid, not full transaction histories. We will also set rules that women can challenge wrong fees and that their access to SokoLink does not depend on automatic fee deductions. These limits will be written explicitly in the MoU.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: My safeguards will include clear purpose limitation, a right for women to opt out of automatic sharing, and a complaint mechanism if the integration results in unfair charges. The MoU will state which data can be accessed, by whom, and for how long.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: I will ensure the link does not become a tool to punish women who speak up by requiring that fee disputes can be raised without losing SokoLink access. Data sharing will be limited and audited, as specified in the MoU, with consequences if the rules are broken.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: I will insist that the integration only shares the bare minimum needed for fee reconciliation, under strict community-approved rules. Women must be able to question fees without fear of being blocked from SokoLink. The MoU will define data purposes, retention periods, independent oversight, and a clear option to suspend or redesign the link if it starts to silence or intimidate traders.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: My safeguards will be co-designed with women. They will include limited data flows, no exclusivity of payment channels, and a safe way to challenge wrong fees. These conditions will be written as firm clauses with monitoring roles and a right to withdraw if women start feeling more controlled than supported.

question_text: The district wants SokoLink to link with their market fee system. What rules and safeguards will you propose so this link does not silence women’s voices, and clear limits on how data is shared?
text: I will propose that any link is tested first as a pilot with strong feedback loops from women, and that the MoU declares explicitly what data will never be shared, such as loan history or political opinions. If monitoring shows that women feel less able to complain after the link, we must have the contractual right to pause or change it.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: I think it is enough if a project staff member goes alone to the radio and explains that SokoLink is safe and good. If people hear it, trust should improve and I will not worry too much about measuring it.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: I will send the communications officer to talk on radio. As long as he explains that the programme is good, I will assume that trust is increasing without checking more deeply.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: For me the radio show will mostly be a chance to advertise SokoLink again. I will not necessarily include community voices or track long-term changes in trust.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: I will invite a staff member and one market woman to speak. They will repeat that data is safe, fees are fair, and SokoLink is here to help. Afterwards I will ask a few traders if they heard it and feel better.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: The speakers will be a project focal person and a local leader. They will emphasise that SokoLink is approved, safe, and beneficial. I will check trust informally during my next field visits.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: We will tell listeners that we listened to their concerns, improved the system, and that they can contact us with questions. I will look at the number of calls and some conversations in the market as rough signs of trust.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: I will bring a mix of voices: a programme staff, a respected woman trader, and a religious or cultural leader. They will repeat that women’s consent matters, fees must be clear, and SokoLink is for better market access, not spying. I will check trust by monitoring uptake, usage by previous sceptics, and the tone of comments during community meetings.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: On air we will have a panel with a partner staff, a trader, and a buyer. They will repeat three messages: your data is protected, fees and conditions are open, and you have a right to ask questions. Beyond likes, I will see if more women choose to opt in voluntarily and whether rumours in our logs start to fade.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: I will ensure that at least one woman trader sits on the panel to tell her story. The three messages will be about consent, fairness, and benefits. I will then track changes in complaints, churn rates, and attendance at our feedback meetings as deeper signs of trust.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: I will choose speakers that people already trust: a market leader who has challenged us before, a woman trader, a buyer, and a staff member. They will repeat three simple truths: your consent comes first, you can see and question your fees, and SokoLink exists to support your business, not others’ politics. I will read trust through long-term patterns; more low-literacy women using SokoLink by choice, fewer fearful rumours, and more people willing to challenge us openly when something seems wrong.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: The show will centre community voices rather than staff alone. A trader, a church or mosque leader, and a buyer will sit alongside us and repeat that women’s dignity, transparent fees, and better access to buyers are the non-negotiables. To see if trust is growing, we will track who adopts SokoLink, how often they return, and whether they now bring new questions rather than silent fear.

question_text: You are planning a radio talk show to rebuild trust. Who will speak on the show, what three key messages will they repeat, and how will you check if trust is growing in ways that go beyond just likes or call-ins?
text: I will treat the radio show as the start of a longer conversation. The speakers will stress that women can say no, that the system is open to scrutiny, and that we are willing to change again. I will assess trust not just by calls but by whether women in the markets feel safe enough to challenge us face-to-face and whether their stories about SokoLink shift from fear to cautious confidence.
